quizzes.title: History Quiz: Seasons and James
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, concertos, welsh. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who wrote, directed, and starred in the 1981 movie The Four Seasons?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alan Alda

questions.question: Which of these actors, named James, is not correctly matched with an Oscar-nominated role he played?

options.text: James Oliver Cromwell - Farmer Arthur Hoggett in Babe
James Caan - Santino Sonny Corleone in The Godfather.
James Stewart - Paul Biegler in Anatomy of a Murder
James Jim Carrey - Truman Burbank in The Truman Show

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Jim Carrey - Truman Burbank in The Truman Show

questions.question: Which of these US Presidents had the shortest tenure?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James A. Garfield

questions.question: Which statement, regarding James VI of Scotland and James I of England, is true?

options.text: They are one and the same person.
They lived two centuries apart and are not related.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They are one and the same person.

questions.question: What is a tuque?

options.text: A type of bikini that became very popular around 2004.
A type of winter snow that falls horizontally in very high latitudes.
A type of fruit that used to be called a winter peach
A winter hat typically worn in Canada.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A winter hat typically worn in Canada.

questions.question: What do we call the longest day of the year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The summer solstice

questions.question: In which season did ancient Greeks celebrate Mothers Day?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spring

questions.question: Name the famous Welsh poet who wrote the poem The Boys of Summer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dylan Thomas

questions.question: What is the name of The Eagles lead singer and drummer who wrote the song The Boys of Summer?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Don Henley

questions.question: What prolific 19th century novelist wrote The Leatherstocking Tales, a series of novels featuring frontiersman Natty Bumppo?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Fenimore Cooper

questions.question: Which of these accomplishments was not made by Captain James Cook, an English explorer, navigator and cartographer?

options.text: He explored a group of small islands in the heart of Polynesia which were later named after him.
He was the first to map Newfoundland.
He was the first European to visit the Hawaiian Islands.
In 1774, he became the first explorer to sight Antarctica.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: In 1774, he became the first explorer to sight Antarctica.

questions.question: When does the vernal equinox occur in the Northern Hemisphere?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: March 20, 21, or 22

questions.question: Who  wrote the concertos called The Four Seasons?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vivaldi

questions.question: Where in the USA would you find the place that in 1921 set a North American record for the largest snowfall in a 24-hour period?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Colorado

questions.question: The book The Boys of Summer tells the story of this baseball team.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Brooklyn Dodgers

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: City and Lakota

questions.question: Look for me by moonlight
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Highwayman

questions.question: In the 14th Century, Moscow replaced this city as the cultural center of Russia.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kiev

questions.question: A book claiming that the story of Wilhelm Tell was just a myth was burned at the stake in Switzerland.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In 1955 pianist Roger Williams had an instrumental hit with this record.

options.text: Why Do I Have Spring Fever

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Autumn Leaves

questions.question: In Greek it is Sayapo, in Lakota it is Techihhila, in Lithuanian it is Tave myliu, in Albanian it is te dua. What is it in English?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: I love you

questions.question: A major earthquake struck this city in 1906, killing almost 3,000 people.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: San Francisco

questions.question: In Scandinavian mythology this is the equivalent of the apocalypse.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: ragnarok

questions.question: How many English words (not proper nouns) begin with dw?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 4

questions.question: Which former US President said I know Im getting better at golf because I hit  fewer spectators.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ford

questions.question: Who composed and performed the ballad Goodbye Yellow Brick Road?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elton John

questions.question: A very common greeting in India is namaste or namaskar. What does it mean?

options.text: I pray your family is complete.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: I bow  to you.

questions.question: Find the quote by Federico Fellini.

options.text: An idea does not pass from one language to another without change.
All language is like a wonderfully long script.
A different language is a different vision of life.
Drawing on my fine command of language, I said nothing.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A different language is a different vision of life.

questions.question: Spanish is an official language of this African country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Equatorial Guinea

questions.question: Which of the following was not a game show host?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walter Bradley

questions.question: What is telesophobia?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fear of being last

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Movie and Person
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, veteran, sitcom. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What was the first movie for the Olsen twins?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Little Rascals

questions.question: Coca Cola was originally green.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Ellis Island was the location of the entry facility used by many immigrants to enter the USA. When did the facility operate?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1892-1954

questions.question: In the sitcom Cheers what was the name of the restaurant that sat above the bar?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Melvilles

questions.question: In how many ways can ough be pronounced in English?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 8

questions.question: He was the first person nominated for the Oscar for Producer (Best Picture), Director, Actor and Screenwriter for the same movie.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Orson Welles

questions.question: Who was the first person to show that blood moved from the heart  to the lungs and back?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: ibn-al-Nasif

questions.question: In what year did the last veteran of the American Civil War die?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1958

questions.question: What does antepenultimate mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: second from last

questions.question: Find the correct statement.

options.text: Irrupt is not a real English word.
Irrupt means  to break in or rush in.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Irrupt means  to break in or rush in.

questions.question: Lawrence Bohune was the first doctor in the British Colony of Virginia. When did he arrive?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1610

questions.question: How did Jerome Napoleon Charles Bonaparte, the last member of the Bonaparte family, die?

options.text: He died of starvation in a German prisoner.
He drowned off the coast of the Island of Elba.
He died a natural death in 1995 at the age of 106.
He died of injuries sustained when he tripped over his dogs leash.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He died of injuries sustained when he tripped over his dogs leash.

questions.question: Eddie Slovik was a soldier killed during World War II. How did he die?

options.text: He was the last US soldier to die in World War II.
He was the first soldier killed on D-Day.
He was shot by the US for desertion.
He was the only American prisoner of war in Hiroshima when the A-bomb fell.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was shot by the US for desertion.

questions.question: Where did the word golf originate?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Scotland

questions.question: In the late 1980s which television station did Rosie ODonnell work for?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: VH1

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Russia

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rene Clair

questions.question: On December 3rd 1967, South African surgeon Christiaan Barnard succeeded in performing what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The first human heart transplant

questions.question: The Greek word hamartia, used in Aristotles Poetics, means what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A fatal flaw

questions.question: Which of these famous American authors is not a Pulitzer Prize winner?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mark Twain

questions.question: The Voltaic pile, known as the first modern electric battery, was invented by Alessandro Volta in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1800

questions.question: German chemist Martin Klaproth discovered uranium in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1789

questions.question: The famous Leporello Catalogue Aria is from which Mozart opera?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Don Giovanni

questions.question: This landlocked Alpine country, whose official Latin name is Confoederatio Helvetica, is a federation of relatively autonomous cantons.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Switzerland

questions.question: This leader, who ruled the Holy Roman Empire from 1792 until 1806, is known as the last Holy Roman Emperor.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Francis II

questions.question: Which of the following planets is not named after a Roman god?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Uranus

questions.question: In what 1997 movie does the following exchange take place?

options.text: rol Connelly: ...Thats maybe the best compliment of my life.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: As Good as It Gets

questions.question: Which statement about Gee Jon, who died on February 8, 1924, at the age of 29, is true?

options.text: He was the last person released from an American internment camp
He was the first American who died in the Northern Expedition in China
He was the first identical twin to survive separation
He was the first person in the USA executed by lethal gas

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was the first person in the USA executed by lethal gas

questions.question: What Rolling Stones member made a cameo appearance in the 2007 movie Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Keith Richards

questions.question: Which of the following was invented by a woman?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: all of these

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pierre Fauchard

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Scarlett OHara (Gone with the Wind)

options.text: She was the first female architect to design a skyscraper.
She was the first female winner of the Pulitzer Prize in Feature Writing
